thread.title: WA strikes deal on NDIS with Commonwealth at last
thread.title_full: WA strikes deal on NDIS with Commonwealth at last

author: Nicolas Perpitch
title: WA strikes deal on NDIS with Commonwealth at last
text:
Western Australia and the Federal Government have finalised a bilateral agreement to operate a state-run version of the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) in the state. 
The two parties had announced in early December they would begin final negotiations on the agreement. 
Unlike other states, which are run under a centralised system, the WA model of the NDIS will be locally run and administered. 
It will be rolled out from July, and it is estimated about 39,000 people will be part of the scheme by the time it is fully operating three years later. 
As part of 11 conditions stipulated by the Commonwealth to ensure national consistency, WA will pay the full administration and operating costs. 
But governance responsibilities will be shared. 
A new WA NDIS authority will be set up to deliver the scheme, and it will be governed by a seven-member independent WA board. Scheme to be nationally consistent and provide clients 'control' 
The state's disability services minister will appoint four board members, and the remaining three will be appointed on recommendation of the Commonwealth minister. 
Federal Social Services Minister Christian Porter said the agreement provided people with a disability choice, control over their services and national consistency on eligibility and access to support services. 
"There were 11 fixed conditions the Commonwealth required for a state-run NDIS in Western Australia to ensure consistency and integrity of the scheme is upheld across the country and I'm very pleased the agreement reflects all of these conditions," Mr Porter said. 
State legislation which mirrors key aspects of the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act will now need to be introduced. 
Premier Colin Barnett had long pushed for a locally-run scheme. 
He said the agreement ensured services would be delivered by people based in WA who knew the communities they worked with. 
"People with disability, their families and carers now have certainty about their future, and can rest assured they will receive the vital support they deserve," Mr Barnett said.
